As always, another outstanding review video!  Let us take a quick look at apple history.  In 2005, had to decide if, I should buy the new white 20 inch G5 iMac (which was the last PowerPC based model) or wait a year or two for the new white Intel 24 inch iMac (that came with both a Fire-wire 400 port and a Fire-wire 800 port).  But because, it was the first generation Intel iMac it did not come with a Core 2 Duo processor and could only be upgraded to Lion.  Glad, I selected correctly and got the 20 inch G5 iMac and, I still use my G5 iMac daily.  Why you may ask, because as a back-up desktop system it runs vintage OS 9 software, early OS X Power PC software, iLife '09, iWorks '09, Micosoft Office, and over the air HD TV viewing and recording using Elgato's EyeTV 500 system.

My first iMac i ever bought was the bare bones first generation aluminum frame with the black panel behind. 1GB of Ram. 250GB hard drive. I upgraded the ram after 7 years of using it full time, with Photoshop and other animation and illustration programs. Went from 1 GB to 3GB of ram, and it breathed new life to my computer. In total I used that thing for 10 years. Yeah, a crazy long time but why I love that machine is because it never had any major issues, and it helped make the art I wanted, even when it didn't have the necessary requirements for. Now since 2017 I'm running a nice- used refurbished late 2010 27 iMac with the fullest specs it had for the time. Awesome machine, only issue with this line was the screen, and I do have some issues with the screen brightness on the bottom left side. Still, overall great machine, and I have had no real issues that are breaking in any way. It does what I want it and it works all around great. I love apple for that reason, their machines, in my luck streak has been great.
I personally love this design, but I am ready for a new design. It will be really cool to see what they come up with next. Just as long they don't get rid of the headphone jack XD

While the movement away from Intel, was a [STRONGLY] inevitable technological move, alongside more economic push [reducing parties involved and holding more money, close to their chest]. It is this more iron-fisted notion, when compared with PowerPC -- Intel transition. That was "relatively" seamless: G4 chips [mainly laptops] were x86 counterparts to Intel 32bit; G5 chips [Desktops] were inline to Intel x86-64 counterparts -- but still had to iron out them PowerPC/Intel instruction swaps. It did take quite a few years, before PowerPC became an invalid spec callout.... OS cycles / software lasted quite a bit longer, before offering some optional internal upgrade / straight system replacement needed for next Mac OSX environment [giving that sensation a well kempt Mac, can last a manaically long while].

Making such specific moves, on the hardware side, also would have in-house / 3rd party software groups, to being under hyper aggressive scrutiny. This transition, is to also contain some emulator dialogue, for these fresh-AF ARM chiplets [to be working off x86-64 instructions]. Mac OSX lifespan being a a bit shorter overall, has performance / utility hampering, being an expected activity... So how long, would a recent purchaser [Gen10 Intel Platform Apple System], truly have with their device being viable, before this scheduled bricking [because Apple swinging their phallus about]?... and thas NOT addressing the Store strong-armed 30% payment shenananaigans, off recent newsreels [+ the Tim v. Tim celebrity deathmatch vouching sabre rattles. "Lets get it on!?"]

This period for Apple, just won't be pretty, compared to recent past Q-earnings / stock rampings, along with plenty of hardware / software woes [+ some perma-lingering lawsuits / settlements]... But then again, they [easily] could've gone heavy on the complacency, with a lot of their product developments [but Intel beat them square, to that punching bag].

Apple stopped selling PowerPC Macs in late 2006 (August 2006 for the PowerMac G5 and November 2006 for the Xserve), the first Intel-only release of OS X was 10.6, which came out in August of 2009, it means that those Macs were supported for three years. I am expecting either the same, or a two year support period after the last Intel Mac stops shipping. The transition haven't started yet (i.e. there are no AS based Macs apart from the developer systems), but we know it's going to take two years, it's fine to buy an Intel Mac if you plan to replace it within 4 or 5 years. Typing this on my Early 2011 13" MacBook Pro), so I will wait for the new Macs, although in February I almost bought a 16" MBP. It‚Äôs already been said, but it needs to be said again: never buy first generation products.  For those who were buyers around the PPC to Intel switch we remember the headaches of non-optimized apps and buggy firmware.  The MacBooks and MacBook Pros transitioned well, but it took apple some time to get the PowerMac‚Äî> MacPro transition done.  And even then lots of people were still using the quad core P:ower Mac G5 for a few years into the reign of the Mac Pro.   Nothing wrong with buying a machine now and upgrading to a new AppleSoC in 2-4 years.  The current MacPro will still last you a decade.  I know audio houses that are just NOW upgrading from dual and quad core PowerMac G5s with PCI-X to Mac Pros.

I don't agree that waiting for the next one is the way to go. If you remember the Motorola to Intel transition, it took quite a time for the major software company to get it right. 2nd, Arm based chip are superior for power consumption but who really care for that kind of desktop machine? Anyway, I hope I'm wrong.

Even if you can wait for Apple silicon - probably not a great idea to wait, just go the intel. Tech reviewers are a bit biased because they‚Äôre excited for the bleeding edge, but most consumers wont benefit that greatly from the change. In particular, the biggest advantage is the power consumption - which isn‚Äôt relevant for a corded iMac anyway. The transition period is going to be marked by some pain with some apps not working, Rosetta wont be perfect. The windows ARM machines for instance shocked consumers when they couldn‚Äôt run many apps, leading the devices to fail. I don‚Äôt think it will be the same, given Rosetta... but I wouldn‚Äôt advise people to ‚Äúearly adopt.‚Äù That‚Äôs a scary idea to recommend to everyone.

If there was no chrome, then Firefox would be king.

comment: I wonder if the last of the high end Intel based macs will become popular on the used market because of the ability to dual or triple boot operating systems on them. I doubt you'll be able to with ARM based macs. A lot of people switched to mac when they started using Intel because they liked Mac OS but had a few windows apps they needed to use and the ability to boot both meant you could now have it all.

Mark bro, you want Fusion drives gone because you can afford 8TB SSDs but there is still people out there who cant even afford a 512GB SSD but they still need Apple performance or Apple dependent softwares hence that 1TB fusion drive is for them. Its good that Apple is still thinking about that niche. It should always be optional in my opinion because I am one of them, I am a Designer from Pakistan and I bought my first MacBook in 2017 because I had to use some softwares to update my skills and I could only afford to buy it with most basic specs & 256 GB SSD which costed me Rs 350,000. which believe me is alot in here. I saved up for 2 years to buy it.

I definitely don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre talking to nobody on the subject of long lifespan users. I would consider myself both a ‚Äúpower user‚Äù (filmmaker,) and I run iMacs on a 8-10yr upgrade plan. I‚Äôll absolutely be running with my current Late 2015 iMac until I see what the new redesigned Metal models look like. The number one thing I hope carries over is the user-upgradable RAM, as Apple‚Äôs OEM prices are pretty insulting. Thanks to a couple tasty aftermarket sticks, my now-5-year-old machine still chews through Raw video, 4K DPX film scans, 5.1 audio mixes... you name it, I can work with it. Sure, renders on larger projects are a walk-away-and-check-later affair, but that‚Äôs a small price to pay for being truly familiar and comfortable with your workstation thanks to years of use. Really, any model newer than mine with a straight SSD in it should work great for quite a long time. I would suspect that 2-3 years into Metal, all the older macs will start to show signs of inefficiency due to the OS simply not being tailor-fit to that architecture anymore, but that‚Äôs still a ways off.

Honestly I think the first ARM Macs will be worse than an X86 one for the first two generations or so.
The best Mac for the coming few years will be this one. I doubt Apple has found a solution to all the things previous hardware solved yet.

The anti glare screen used to come standard, or as an option for Apple laptops. I had the 12" PowerBook G4 (2003),  and the MacBook Pro 15" (2008), which both had the anti glare screens. My 2015 and 2019 MacBook Pros did not come with that option and I had to by anti glare screen protectors. Friends and coworkers would look over my shoulder and ask why I would choose to make my screen mat when the laptop has retina display. Well, fewer headaches and not having to turn off all of my lights to reduce glare are two good reasons.

Trust me, as a professional musician, you don't want a mac in the middle of a tech transition. the IBM to Intel move was UGLY, and frankly detrimental to a music career. It turns out music software manufacturers (of plugs not just daws) team's aren't that big, and in some cases we had to wait 4 years for some to gather the resources to re-tool and re-code for the new format. If you happen to rely on anything 3rd party then it's in potential jeopardy.

Good review, as usual. Love the transition from the pro grade cam to the updated webcam, perfect way to make the difference clear. Would have been cool to have yet a third transition to the same shot on an older iMac webcam to see the improvement, but yeah can't ask for that much additional work :)

I do have a point about the mac lineup though, which I wish more tech reviewers took up. Apple's lineup of computers (i.e. non-iPhone/iPad devices) are terribly lacking for anyone that is actually working with macs, that is pro-grade hardware not intended for rendering or content creation type tasks. I'll try to illustrate using myself as an example but I believe this is a fairly common scenario for those of us who are long-term mac users and committed to the apple ecosystem.

Let's say you have a macbook from your work and you do home office as well as a private computer setup. As things stand now (and have been for a long time) there is no good way to have a versatile setup. As it is now, there is no way to use an iMac as "display-only" with the processing done on the work laptop. So you go get yourself an external display, but if you want to work on your side projects "off the clock" the external screen just sits next to your iMac unused, since their colors and brightness will likely not match. Alternative is to buy an apple computer without an integrated display, then your options are a Mac Mini (which is way too weak and not a good long-term investment) and a Mac Pro which is clearly overkill for most people and also atrociously priced. I refused to buy an apple computer with my own money for a long long time, and I don't see that changing anytime soon.

The desirable solution would be to add a desktop computer that hits the sweet spot between a mac mini and mac pro, but the simplest solution would be to allow an iMac to be set into a display only mode, which I honestly don't get why they removed. Any comments on that would be awesome!

I honestly am not sure how to take the transition as far as performance estimates. Usually the first iterations of a new architecture, are notoriously flawed.
Examples: Windows Vista, Pentium 4 (Netburst), IA64, Windows Me, Windows XP (Pre-Sp1), etc...
So...it's probably a good idea to go with the last of the intel macs, because they'll at least be supported for a few years, after which you MIGHT not be able to get to the latest release, but you still are able to function and do what is needed for at least a few years longer.

Getting on the new platform early, has its own issues. Bugs, variances, miscalculations, etc that could cause hardware or software bugs. Things as simple as a cpu scheduler caused massive issues with amd chips at first, until they ironed things out. Usually the first version, is the overpriced beta that people attach to and fix before the mainstream jumps on. If waiting, I would wait for AT LEAST the second generation of the new platform before jumping on.....possibly even the third to ensure that the platform is going to stick. Had people that chosen the Itanium taken this advice, they would have bought xeons instead of itaniums and been better off when intel finally admitted it was a failure and retired it....

Thank you for a great review and overall awesome information.  I might be a bit biased being a retired Intel (open source, Linux) Software Engineer.  However, I try to remain objective and express my professional and experience-based opinion.  The transition to Apple Silicon (ARM RISC Architecture) might look impressive and promising on the drawing board and even in the early prototypes and testing.  However, as a Mac user since Apple switched to X86, I have invested a lot in Apple hardware and the Mac.  I own both the 16" MBP and 2019 iMac (Core i9).  To me, MacOS + Apple's Hardware are the best "Linux" Desktop (just my opinion).  Switching to RISC presents a lot of questions.  Device Drivers, peripheral support, 3rd party hardware, cross & backward compatibility and power-performance optimization.  Besides the technical issues, Apple is leaving behind a whole (established) eco-system around X86 and entering the unknown universe of proprietary silicon.  Will apple be able to remain competitive as Intel and AMD find new ways to extend Moore's Law? What about POSIX and other IEEE standards compliance? Tool-chain, benchmarks, etc.? Let's look at nVidia's, Samsung's and even Microsoft's attempts to offer ARM based Hardware and learn from it.  I am rooting for Apple to succeed in transitioning with the least amount of negative impact on (me) the consumer and developer, because I truly appreciate my current Apple products (iCloud not so much) and it will be painful, disappointing and costly; if I was to go back to Linux (or [scary] Windows 10) just to restore my setup, environment and productivity only because of the CPU.  Thank you

I think what's interesting and which people aren't really talking about is Apple's presence and future in the consumer desktop (not pro- not laptop) space. Apple saw fit to pretty much not innovate the iMac since 2012 other than spec bumps (the iMac Pro was really no more than a big spec bump & better cooling) which says a lot about the relevant importance of the iMac in their product line-up and as a market sector. The question is, does Apple neglecting the iMac for the best part of a decade point the way to its future? E.g. we'll get the Apple silicon, we'll get a new 2020-2021 design with maybe one or two innovations from other products and we'll then wait another ten years with just spec bumps. Is the consumer desktop market so constrained that it's difficult to innovate in this space, because what desktop users do doesn't really change that much?

I don't think we'll wait a long time for great improvements to new Silicon Mac computers, even for iMacs. From what I've heard, Intel had been holding Apple back for years due to some issues. With silicon, Apple might be able to update the iMacs just like how they update their mobile devices, even if it's just more frequent spec bumps. We'll see what happens though.

3:58: Actually, the first difference I noticed in the video was that the glass around the screen seemed to be an odd, very pure black, which would usually be a bit more reflective and, well, less of a pure ventablack-like colour. The bezel is so dark, that I wouldn't be surprised if the pixel data of it was entirely (0, 0, 0). I'm not sure I've ever seen such a pure black background for a screen before.

8:28: I actually do like using my electronics for as long as possible. I look at electronics news more for entertainment than actually purchasing things, because it's really fun to see what's new but often my current electronics work perfectly fine, especially those that can be upgraded. My phone is from 2014 and my PC was built in 2016 with a CPU, motherboard, and RAM from about 2009.

Since I don't have that much money, I also love to get things used that used to be top of the line (or just really high end) at some point, but which are now much cheaper (like my CPUs, Intel Xeon X5560s, that originally cost over $1000 each but cost $30 for both when I bought them in 2016). A few years after the last Intel Mac is made, it may be interesting to buy one of them and have the best possible Intel/Mac machine, or, if/when Intel becomes obsolete in PCs in general, to buy the best possible Intel machine available period. I really love old hardware that used to be expensive but is now dirt cheap, because that means I can have something that is the best in its class in at least one category.

So, I don't think you're preaching to nobody... though to be fair, I wasn't in the market for a Mac anyway, because self-built Linux PCs can last quite a bit longer while still staying lightning fast. Not that Macs aren't good Linux machines either, though. I originally switched to Gentoo Linux on my 2007 MacBook 3,1 around 2015, since Linux had much better game support due to being updated much more than Mac OS X 10.6.8, while also being faster than Mac OS X 10.6.8, and MUCH faster than Mac OS X 10.7.2 (which was really slow on my old MacBook compared to 10.6.8).

But the point is, one can still be a tech enthusiast interested in learning about all the latest gadgets, without necessarily actually buying them. Tech is really fun, but I have no need to stress the environment and my wallet actually buying everything when my existing technology still works great and nice channels like yours let me see all the latest stuff too :) .

Fittingly, the first person who ever described The Osborne Effect to me was Steve Jobs himself in a conversation on the rationale behind Apple‚Äôs then-renowned secrecy over product roadmaps and production pipelines. He also always held the power of stopping any project in its tracks if he felt necessary without the pressure of any announced consumer or developer release dates. So frankly I found it stunning when Tim Cook announced Apple Silicon now. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù I asked myself. When Steve Jobs announced Intel Macs, he ALSO revealed OS X‚Äôs ‚Äúsecret double life‚Äù and amazed the audience that such a huge transition that took them years to achieve had already been well completed before the world at large heard one word about it. I think Apple Silicon is a great advancement and I‚Äôm sure there was a lot of pressure on them to reveal these efforts given Apple has been criticized in recent years for seemingly not innovating as rapidly or as substantially as years past. But The Osborne Effect looms large here and I‚Äôm all but certain it will put a dent in Mac sales. Using myself as a prime example, if I had no clue Apple Silicon was coming I would‚Äôve unquestionably already placed my order for this new iMac. But expressly because I remember how from one day to the next my G4 iMac became a doorstop, the only Intel Macs I want are the ones I already own. I will be ordering my Apple Silicon iMac the very day they take the first orders for them and I am only too happy to wait for that day to come. I can‚Äôt imagine that Apple didn‚Äôt consider the millions of us that will wait out this transition so my only explanation as to why they went ahead and announced it now anyway is that they just don‚Äôt care. They‚Äôve become big enough and rich enough that this will just be a blip in their stats where other companies that made this error went bankrupt doing such a thing. When the rumors first started swirling that Apple had dropped Intel CPUs on the Mac, I was all but certain that, if true, we‚Äôd be seeing the first Apple Silicon Macs right now. So I gotta be honest... I‚Äôm baffled about why they chose to announce it this way. And I‚Äôm reminded how much I miss Steve Jobs, who always had great restraint on this because the reveal was just as important to him as the product itself. Peace and thanks to everyone who read this crazy long comment. Hope you got something out of it.

I suspect the Osborne Effect won't matter for this product. For one, Apple doesn't actually need this product to make any sales at all unlike the original Osborne company. Secondly, for those companies and individuals who want the known stability of the current Intel platform for as long as possible, this device is a no-brainer. While we tech enthusiasts love to live on the bleeding edge, most businesses do not.¬†Lastly, it could be quite a while until an Apple Silicon replacement for this device is released - the 21.5 iMac didn't receive a chip bump this time, so I suspect it may get the big redesign first. We might be waiting a while longer for a true 27" significant upgrade so Apple can focus on building a more powerful chip for a bit longer. I've been spoilt by the larger 27" display, so I'd rather they didn't replace both the 21.5" and 27" with a tweener bezel-less 24", but who knows?

Fears over buying now because of unknown and possibly early retirement? It‚Äôs actually pretty easy to predict longevity based on history. Probably two years until a refresh with SoC specs that can match higher end Intel products shipping now. Three years beyond that until the last consumer Intel machine drops off support. That‚Äôs four minimum and more likely five years based on averages. Then there are all those corporate customers that are always the last to move. Add another year or two for them to move before support ends for good. Now you are approaching six or even seven years before real EOL sets in. I‚Äôve pushed a few of my Macs another three years beyond that point. Only now is El Capitan finally reaching a point where it is no longer viable for day-to-day use. That‚Äôs ten years of life for the earliest machines that could be updated as far as El Cap. At worst, the architecture transition might trim three years off that number, or one support cycle - doubtful, but it COULD happen. That‚Äôs still seven years. Not bad.

Even if the SoC transition accelerates faster than expected, people will still be able to extract years out of a buying decision they make now. Yeah, maybe they can‚Äôt claim ‚Äúlatest design‚Äù status for as long, but that is mostly marketing hype anyway. Nobody walks into a another person‚Äôs house and says ‚Äúoh my god, that bezel, and those rounded corners!‚Äù Doesn‚Äôt happen in real life. What a person buys today will still work as well as it did the day before the new model arrived, and they will continue to get updates until the very last Intel drops off the support list.

I would not hesitate to buy now because of fears over obsolescence. Buy if one needs to and don‚Äôt look back. There‚Äôs always something better coming. Rest assured it will still be there the next time one is in the market.

I ordered a iMac 5K, core-i9, Radeon Pro 5700 XT 16 GB, 10 gb ethernet, and 4 TB SSD.

My last primary was an iMac 5K purchased in desperation in late 2018 when my 2014 was going into the shop, and the core-i9 model was tardy. The year old 2017 I was forced to buy was top-of-the-line at the time, but it really wasn't much faster than the 2014. The model I really wanted was released a few months later with a core-i9 8 core and better graphics. (Thanks Intel.)

The 2017 has a core-i7 4 core 8 thread with a 3 TB fusion drive - they only offered a 2 TB SSD which wasn't big enough (as I had a 3 TB fusion in the 2014) and was ludicrously expensive.

The 2020 iMac with a core-i9 has 10 cores 20 threads which should tear through my 7-10 hour transcodes much more quickly, and this will be the last and most powerful consumer level Intel Mac produced. The Radeon Pro 5700 XT 16 GB should have 40 compute units which should be tons faster than my current Radeon Pro 580 8GB, and the new machine is capable of boot camp, so I will have the ability to boot into Windows and play most AAA games as fast as any Mac ever has.

The Mac has had a relatively small number of AAA games, and of that number many were culled by Catalina going 64 bit only. Boot camp will open up a whole host of titles and will allow 32 bit Windows games as well.

This Mac should tide me over for the transition, and all Mac software which runs under Catalina should continue to work fine while early Apple silicon adopters find and iron out all the painful bumps in the road for me üôÇ.

By the time I'm ready to move on to an Apple silicon iMac maybe AAA game developers may find interest in the performance of that machine, or there may be x86 hypervisors that can run Windows games at native speed. Failing that, I can get a Apple silicon Mac and a cheap Windows gaming machine. I'm retired now, so if AAA titles do start to appear on the Mac, I can just move on and forget Windows ever existed üòä.

It's amazing how much top-of-the-line has changed in three years.

being able to use iPad apps on the Apple silicon macs will be a huge plus. Think how much cheaper IOS apps are to their desktop equivalients. Also sometimes there is ONLY an iPad/android app these days, for example I recently got a Spark 40 guitar amp, that needs either an IOS or Android device to access the full feature list. So, I happen to be one of those folks who keeps using a computer for well over 5 years. After Apple no longer provided OS updates for my 2011 Mac Mini, I went ahead and installed Ubuntu Linux on it. It gave my Mac Mini new life because I now have a fully patched, modern OS installed on it. It still performs well because Linux is a very lightweight OS. I didn't have to throw it away or sell it because my Mac Mini still works just fine. I figured that since Unix is at the heart of macOS then Linux should work just fine and it does. Bluetooth works. Wifi works. Ethernet works. Audio and Video works.

I essentially did a bit of research over the course of a couple of weeks and found reasonable free and open source Linux alternatives to the macOS applications that I was using and switched to those. I was also using my Mac Mini (back when I had OS X installed) to also run Windows via Bootcamp. Under Linux you can dual boot or just install Oracle Virtualbox and run Windows within a virtual machine.

I found a few easy-to-follow YouTube videos on how to install Linux on a Mac. It's a very straightforward process, so if you just want to keep your (still working) Mac hardware (as I do), then this is the way to do it because Linux will continue to receive security updates for years.

Covering the other people. Apple announced nothing prematurely. They announced their architecture shift at WWDC. Their developer's conference. Something like this NEEDS to be announced early to developers so they can start getting their software ready. That announcement was not intended for consumers. Zero Apple Silicon Macs have been announced as of yet so for an average consumer to put off purchasing for some non-existent product that hasn't even been announced is ridiculous.

iMacs won't see an architecture shift this year. This recent refresh has proven that beyond all doubt. They have promised support of Intel Macs for years to come yet. The two year target is for transitioning their entire product line. Meaning new Intel Macs will still be in circulation in the mean time. Then, there will be at least another three to four years of OS updates from the completion of the hardware transition bare minimal. This will give buyers of a new Mac this year a solid five or six years at least. From what I've heard a MacOS version stops receiving updates after two years. That gives a solid year minimal from the year the final version of MacOS to support intel is released.

Even then, providing you are careful you can still be perfectly fine to stick with the last supported MacOS version for another couple of years or so. This ain't like still running XP on a Windows machine without security software. Just don't allow unsigned apps to run after security updates stop and you're fine. The price of SSDs has NOT come down. It irritates me when people keep saying this regarding Macs. In general, maybe, although even then they're nowhere NEAR as affordable as HDDs. Mac SSDs have NOT come down in price however. You try and spec up to a 1TB SSD and see the price skyrocket. Whereas you can get a fushion drive, which is STILL a superfast SSD for your OS and apps for the same price as the shockingly pathetic 256GB SSD they're now including with the Macs as standard.

256GB isn't enough storage for a desktop machine. I don't wanna have to be forced to buy external storage where I wouldn't have had to usually. This decision should ONLY have been made if and when prices of SSDs had come down enough for them to not make compromises on storage. I mean, what the hell was the point of them launching the fusion drive in the first place if they were suddenly gonna pull a fast one like this? I don't blame Apple. I blame influencial tech reviewers complaining about the Fusion Drive and calling it obsolete when they clearly don't understand what it is/how it works.

The magic combination has always been SSD for the system, HDD for mass storage. You don't NEED an SSD for file storage unless you're a professional with very specific requirements. A Fusion Drive is not an SSHD. It's not a HDD for tiny SSD cache. It's an NVME SSD (fairly small but enough for the core system) and a HDD in a single, logical volume which causes the software to see them as a single disk. You're still booting from an SSD. You're still launching your most common apps from an SSD. You just get the best of both worlds. The speed of an SSD removing the prime bottleneck of a PC and the affordability of a bulky HDD for storage.

Lots of tech reviewers and similar seem to miss the third reason for buying a new Intel Mac, right now. Software compatibility.

I was at the point I had to replace my main machine, which was a MacBook Pro 15", with a new computer. Because I don't really need a laptop for this job, I opted for a Mac Mini (with the i7). The reason I made sure to purchase this machine before the Apple Silicon hits us is pretty straightforward -- software compatibility. The computer's main job is running Ableton Live 10. This software will not likely support macOS 11 until it's upgraded, and I can't be sure when it get that update. It will also very likely be a paid upgrade, i.e. to Ableton Live 11. My option was wait until Live was upgraded (timeline unknown) then replace my computer, paying for the software upgrade (couple hundred dollars at least) and the new computer all at once, or, just upgrade now. Without any information on what's coming, I thought it likely that the Mini would be one of the first updated (given it's the frame for the Apple Silicon dev machine), and as I wanted a desktop rather than a laptop,¬†I had to pull the trigger earlier than I needed to in order to ensure compatibility.

Of course if I can afford it I will get a new laptop with the Apple Silicon in the new year.

I'm sure it's also a small percentage, but anyone who wants to dual boot Windows would probably be looking pretty hard at this, since Boot Camp goes away with the silicon switch.

On one hand, Apple silicon is a year out and x86 compatibility over the years will surely degrade - you may not get any more updates to your favorite app 5 years down the line.

But on the other hand, you probably DON'T want to be an early adopter of Apple silicon if you're planning to keep a computer for 10 years. It will potentially take years and a few revisions to get the performance you've come to expect from x86, iron out bugs, and port all the apps you know over to the new architecture. It will also take years for these devices to saturate the market, not just because of the slow rollout of new devices with ARM, but also because there will only be so many people buying devices from each generation.

So for a long time, you'll likely be alone with way less developer support on ARM, similar to how it took a year or two before 3rd party devs started fully embracing the Nintendo Switch - not until they saw device sales and attach rates and realized they had an audience.

It may be worthwhile to get this computer instead of the first generation Apple Silicon. Having been through the previous transitions, the first generation Intel Mac was the core duo which was not 64-bit capable. The 2006 Core Duo Mac mini was obsolete almost as soon as it was released. The first year of PowerPC (1994) was all 601 chips. The next year brought the substantially more powerful 604.

It‚Äôs not just transition devices, either. First generation Apple hardware is not always the best. The first generation iPhone was quickly replaced with a 3G. The Apple TV was replaced with a smaller, faster version. The iPod and iPad both underwent significant changes from the first generation. Second generation AirPods are much better than the first gen.

Some companies may do well to purchase the end of the Intel Macs and let the rest of us deal with those first generation woes.

I honestly think that it could be seen as an incentive that this will likely be the last iMac running on x86 architecture. Usually the last generation of a product is the best and most refined in it's family, while the first generation of a new product line, while novel, is also the buggiest and still has ways to go before all the kinks are ironed out. Plus, there's the matter of software. I'm sure Apple will have all of their software suite ready to go on the new ARM Macs when they launch, but the same can't be guaranteed with third party software. So, if you're looking to buy a Mac purely for the purpose of using third party software like the Adobe Suite, or anything else, you might be pushed to get this before you can no longer get anything like it.

Everytime Apple has left Intel, their hardware has failed.

The sega chipped Macs failed. The PPC Macs failed.

ARM chips can't do what x86 does.

How is ARM gonna effect appa like FCP, Logix and even Adobe top end software?

I think the Apple fanboys are gonna get a rude awakening. Intel will too. But with a strong PC market, intel will not miss Apple.

Applw only sells maybe 2-3M Mac's in a year. That translates to not much mkney when you consider there are 5 Windows PC OEMs who sell as much as 10x the amount of product.

Apple switching to its own chips, is just a way to for them to charge the same, but the chips will be cheaper creating more profit.

I would say, everyone should get the fastest Intel based Mac as long as you can still run Windows and keep it.

Watch the newer ARM based Macs as they struggle for the first 2 or 3 years, because these will have all the problems.

Next, Apple will create supplemental chips that will handle some side processing to help curb the performance breakdowns.

For example, an ARM GPU is gonna suck at console quality gaming. But with a couple of co-processors, those bottlenecks will be handled and help give a decent boost.

On paper and benches, Apple chipa "looks" like it can compete with x86.

But if you look at real world, we can already see that x86 apps simple were not designed for ARM and performance is dismal.

It is like emulation. Today's PCs are several times more powerful than older consoles, yet when trying to play many older games, became software is teying ro mimic what hardware does, it still works slower than the actual real console.

ARM has already killed Intel on mobile, only because Intel never made a serious mobile push.

Maybe now they will get more serious. If they do and make competive performing chips, they will simply transition all their present customers over, which again will dwarf everyone else.

I cant wait to see how the first iMac ARM will be.

Here's the thing though, the Apple Silicon isn't ANY product UPGRADE. It's a new platform in itself. There is no guarantee of things going as smoothly as they are on the current intel line, largely due to the reason of the development cycle being so long. Add to it the fact that we still don't know if all developers will be able to port to the new platform whilst maintaining their performance. So the Osborne Effect argument seems a little moot to me. I see no reason as to why someone looking to update their 2010 machines should really put their purchase off for 2 more years, only to be a tester for a virgin product/platform mix. Buy what you were gonna buy anyway, and by the time this gets old, the new versions would've ironed out their kinks. You get the best of BOTH versions in a way and a DEFINITE value for money.
That's my two cents on this.

My i5 3570k based system has been going solid for 8+ years and I don't expect it to be out of date any time soon. AKA I can still game at 1080p@60 just fine on it with the 970. So CPUs being outdated doesn't happen like it use to. And one can blame both AMD and Intel for that. I didn't feel like it was worth upgrading my PC until Ryzen on AMD's side and Coffee Lake on Intels side with the increase in Core count. Intel was dragging their heels on the CPU side of things for YEARS and that is why my i5 3570k is still solid. You can partly blame the lack of Compitation from AMD for that since Bulldozer was pure garbage and everything based on it going forward was as well. Once Intel got Sandy Bridge out it was OVER for AMD and Intel basically dragged their heels from then on until coffee lake. So yeah a PC from 8 years ago is still solid for basic tasks today. I would still be using a Thinkpad T420 with its Sandy brdige based i5 2520m today if I didn't need better performance in both the GPU and CPU side of things. Got an i7 7700HQ and a 1060 to replace the i5 and Nvidia NVS 4200m and it was a needed upgrade for me personally. It is basically like taking the i5 3570k+970 on the road since they are similar in performance.

People should remember that it's not just about Intel macs becoming obsolete, it's that there will soon be new software coming out for mac that you won't be able to run at all on your Intel mac.
I missed the PPC to Intel transition, but I had a 68k mac that we bought during the 68k to PPC transition (both were on the market at the time). It was fine for a year or two, but then software started coming out that was PPC-only, and before too long, the vast majority of software was PPC-only, as developers either decided that it wasn't worth compiling for 68k macs, or that they weren't fast enough to run their software.
In short: do not buy an Intel mac. Wait for ARM macs. If you buy an Intel mac today, you will regret it in a few years.

Don't get me wrong, I use linux everyday for work, but I do miss several productivity software which are either only available on windows or are just simply more optimised on windows (MS Office is a big one, and no, Libreoffice and Open office don't come close to the level of efficiency, responsiveness and third-party templates/scripts/macros support of MS Office). Then you also have industry-standard software such as Adobe CC which just aren't officially available on Linux. Now one can argue that there are methods to get these software working on Linux, through custom scripts, soft emulation, wine etc, but the fact of the matter is I want to get on with work and not spend hours on setting up these things, only to see them break upon the next update.

Also, after a long day of work, I just want an OS that works when I want it to do something or install something and does not want me to satisfy a dependency hell to install something that isn't already mainstream or if some package got updated and broke things (for example, struggling to get rdp working on linux right now because some GSM audio codec library is broken and can't get it fixed upon reinstalls either).

And, as you said, games. Windows just does those things better for a regular user, and gone are the days where Linux felt tons lighter and more responsive than Windows on the same hardware

I think that there's another side to consider: what if certain people use boot camp to run Windows or have apps and programs that run on x86 natively? Right now, this seems like a solid final hoorah to the current iMacs and someone getting this might be their safe bet. Sure, Apple will inevitably phase Intel Macs out, but I don't think that they will phase them out after those 2 years. Given that the Mac Pro came out in late 2019. I'm sure they're cognizant enough about those who own Intel Macs to ditch them so soon. I own a 2012 13" Macbook Pro and it will not get the Big Sur update. It's just hitting that 9 year mark. Mind you, I didn't get this about 6 years ago though, but it's been running smooth, albeit with an SSD and a slight bump in RAM. The transition of their entire lineup is 2 years, but they never said that that's when their support for Intel Macs will end. "...Years to come," was what was said about support for the Intel based Macs, but given their track record, I'd be inclined to trust them. While heading into the unknown(ish), Apple might transition seamlessly into their own silicon SoC system for future Macs, but perhaps this might be the final steady and reliable Mac to some who work with x86 programs natively. Who knows? Getting tech these days is a gamble because once you buy them, they're already moving onto the next. I think this is a great option for those who were looking to upgrade, but not wishing to be early adopters of next gent tech.

About replacing it - As long as Apple doesn't solder it in that would always be the way to go, but it doesn't resolve the fact that Apple is ripping off it's unknowing customers.
.

@Obsidian Buy your own and put it in yourself then? And the speed is 100% down to Intel being cuntwaffles. That's literally the fastest officially supported RAM their chips work with. They consider anything higher an "overlock". The RAM pricing is also something most OEM's do, it's always stupid expensive. They price it at the high end of the market swings, they just don't adjust it based on current pricing. Remember a few years ago where prices were like 300% higher than even a few months earlier because companies like Samsung were colluding to keep them artificially high (again)?

@TalesOfWar TBH, it's a pointless conversation anyway. They charge $600 to add an extra 24GB of 2666 DDR4 RAM. If you wanted to - you could go look up what that actually costs, and then you'll see why this isn't about size or volume... or any other acceptable justification. It's simply what they believe someone will pay.

@TalesOfWar It's not double the size and it's low volume on both parts. Hell the process might even be done before the glass is cut down to size. The reality is that they know someone buying a $5k display is more likely to spend $1k on it, where someone spending $1,700 (for a whole computer) isn't. (Granted you could spec one up much higher but still). Bottom line, Apple doesn't do value - they simply gouge as much money from their customers as humanly possible.
@Obsidian It's still a physically larger piece of glass and it's also on a much lower volume selling part. They can cover the costs easier on a mainstream product like the iMac.

@Anomaly Detection Algorithm They've already sunk the money into research and development. It makes more sense to switch to ARM because it's more efficient (therefore uses less power and outputs less heat). Intel CPUs make too much heat nowadays which causes a lot of problems for the form factor that Apple is trying to move toward in their desktops and laptops. By using their own ARM chips, they can maintain that form factor and crank out some extra power and/or battery life.

Like I said though, we'll have to see where it goes. But from the benchmarks of the ARM Mac Mini, it sounds like it'll be a pretty good future for the Mac lineup if Apple is successful at creating a desktop-grade chip.
Enchanted Goose and wouldn't it increase profit margins to stick with a desktop brand so they don't sink tons of money into R&D

Akira Kurusu That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs occurring over a two year period and why developers have already received ARM Mac Minis. It lets them start porting their apps over now. Even then, if they won‚Äôt or don‚Äôt want to port their apps over to ARM, isn‚Äôt that what Rosetta 2 is for? Sure, it‚Äôs not going to be as efficient as a native app, but it certainly still allows for the use of x86-64 apps.
rgs _ kn it doesn't make sense to me, or actual professionals who will use the products. Maybe for prosumers, ARM will work. But for professionals? They need proper Intel or AMD chips

@Anomaly Detection Algorithm Apple Silicon doesn't though, it uses ARM architecture. I could be wrong but seeing as emulation is needed to run programs made for AMD64 on ARM chips, I figured emulation would also be necessary to do the opposite.
That being said, I agree Windows programs run well on both Intel and AMD processors because wether they run on an AMD processor or an Intel one, the architecture is similar (AMD64 is an extension of x86)
I think it‚Äôs a great device for non-professionals who want a powerful machine running macOS and don‚Äôt care too much about design
